title-group.article-title: Estimation of Low-Level Radiation Dose from Some Building Materials Using Gamma Spectroscopy

abstract.p: The study of the radiation hazards from building materials is of interest in many countries. So, it becomes necessary to study the natural radioactivity in different materials to assess the dose for the population to know the health risks and to have a baseline for future changes in the environmental radioactivity due to human activities. The present study assesses the level of terrestrial gamma radiation and associated dose rates from the naturally occurring radionuclides 226Ra, 232Th and 40K in building materials collected from the Northeastern part of Haryana state of India using gamma ray spectrometry. Places are in the vicinity of Shivalik range of Himalayas. The activity of radium, thorium and potassium in various soil samples varied from 27 ± 1.2 to 51 ± 1.5 Bq/kg, 42 ± 1.5 to77 ± 2.3 Bq/kg and 277 ± 3.2 to 584 ± 6.1 Bq/kg and in various building materials varied from 14 ± 0.4 to 87 ± 7.7 Bq/kg, 6 ± 0.3 to 24 ± 1.1 Bq/kg and 26 ± 0.4 to 245 ± 3.7 Bq/kg, respectively. The values of absorbed annual effective doses (indoors and outdoors) were found to vary in various soil samples from 50 to 95 nGyh−1, 0.24 to 0.46 mSv and 0.06 to 0.12 mSv and in various building materials found to vary from 11 to 57 nGyh−1, 0.05 to 0.28 mSv and 0.01 to 0.07 mSv, respectively.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The growing worldwide interest in natural radiation exposure has led to extensive surveys in many countries. Human population is always exposed to ionizing radiation from natural radiations arising from within and outside the earth [1]. The natural terrestrial gamma radiation dose rate is an important contribution to the average dose rate received by the world's population. Natural radioactivity is widespread in the earth's environment, and it exists in various geological formations in soils, rocks, plants, water and air [2–4]. The high geochemical mobility of radionuclides in the environment allows them to move easily and to contaminate much of the environment with which humans come in contact. Therefore, measurement of natural radioactivity due to gamma rays from the dose rate is needed to implement the precautionary measures whenever the dose is found to be above the recommended limits. External sources of terrestrial radiation originate from the natural radioactive elements, principally the gamma radiation emitted from 40K and decay products in the 238U and 232Th decay series present in the ground and building materials [5]. These radionuclides constitute natural sources of indoor and outdoor radiation exposure as well as internal and external radiation exposure. Uranium occurs in minerals such as pitchblende and uraninite. It is also found in phosphate rock, lignite and monazite sands.

Isotope 222Rn, a descendant of 238U formed from the radioactive decay of 226Ra, is a colourless, odourless, electrically uncharged noble but hazardous gas which is radioactive, emits alpha radiation and decays with a half life of 3.824 days. The short-lived decay products of radon are responsible for most of the hazards by inhalation. When radon decays to form its progenies, it can attach electrostatically to tiny dust (aerosol) particles, water vapors, oxygen, trace gases in indoor air and other solid surfaces. Aerosol particles are inhaled and attach to the bronchial epithelium, producing a high local radiation dose. The major source of radiation dose to humans is the inhalation of radon (222Rn), thoron (220Rn) and their progenies that are the descendants of the primordial radionuclides present in soil, rocks and building materials and released into ambient air. Radon and its progenies are the most important radioactive and potentially hazardous elements, ubiquitously present as indoor air pollutants in homes and workplaces to which all persons are exposed [6,7]. The radiation dose received by the human population due to the inhalation of radon and its progeny contribute more than 50% of the total dose from natural sources [8,9]. A relationship between lung cancer and the inhalation of radon and its progenies has been demonstrated [10]. At high radon levels, exposure leads to high risks of developing lung cancer, even surpassing that of cigarette smokers [11,12]. Radon is a well-established human carcinogen for which extensive data are available. It is well known that the exposure of a population to high concentrations of radon and its daughters for a long period leads to pathological effects like respiratory functional changes and the occurrence of lung cancer [13]. Various researchers have reported that exposure to high levels of radon at the workplace and in other public-sector indoor settings are important risk factors for lung cancer for workers [14]. The United States Environmental Protection Agency has reported that inhalation of radon is the second killer from cancer [15]. The health hazards caused by radon and thoron are not primarily due to these isotopes but due to their short-lived daughters that are inhaled. The gamma radiation dose is then evaluated and could be of great interest to manufacturers, the National Regulatory Board and construction companies [16].
Therefore, the knowledge of natural radionuclides concentration levels and their distribution in the environment have become a focus of much attention in assessing the human exposure.

The aim of this study is focused on determining the level of terrestrial gamma radiation and associated dose rates from activity concentrations of 226Ra, 232Th and 40K in soil as well as in some building materials. The activity concentrations of 226Ra, 232Th and 40K in soil and building materials were estimated by high-resolution gamma ray spectrometry technique. The samples have been quantitatively identified based on the characteristic spectral peaks. This study is important from a radiation protection point of view.

sec.title: Estimation of Activity of Radium, Thorium and Potassium
sec.p: For the estimation of radium, thorium and potassium, eight samples of soil and six samples of other building materials were collected. After collection, each sample was crushed into a fine powder by using mortar and pestle. Before measurement, each sample was filtered and dried in an oven at about 110°C for 24 h to remove the moisture content. Each sample was packed and sealed in an airtight PVC (Polyvinyl chloride) container and kept for about 4-week period (>7 days half-lives of 222Rn and 224Ra) to allow the radioactive equilibrium among the radon (222Rn), thoron (220Rn) and their short-lived progenies.

The technique of gamma spectrometry was used to measure the levels of radioactivity in various samples used [17,18]. Radioactivity measurements were performed using high-purity germanium (HPGe) detectors at Inter-University Accelerator Centre, New Delhi. The detector is a coaxial n-type HPGe detector (EG&G, ORTEC, Oak Ridge). The detector having a resolution of 2.0 keV at 1332 keV, and a relative efficiency of 20% was placed in 101.6-mm shield of lead bricks on all sides to reduce the background radiation from the materials and cosmic rays [19]. The output of the detector was analyzed using a 4 K ADC system connected to PC, the spectrum was analyzed using the locally developed software “Collection and Analysis of Nuclear Data using Linux nEtwork” (CANDLE). For calibration of the low background counting system, a secondary standard was obtained, which was calibrated with the primary standard obtained from the International Atomic Energy Agency. The efficiency for the system was determined using secondary standard source of uranium ore in the same geometry as available for the sample counting. Efficiency values were plotted against energy for particular geometry and were fitted by least squares method to an empirical relation that took care of the nature of efficiency curve for the HPGe detector. For activity measurements, the samples were counted for a period of 72,000 s, and the spectra were analyzed for the photopeak of uranium, thorium daughter products and K-40. The activity concentration of 40K (CK) was directly measured by its own gamma ray of 1461 keV. As 226Ra and 232Th are not directly gamma emitters, their activity concentrations (CRa and CTh) were measured through gamma rays of their decay products. Gamma transitions of 1461 keV for 40K, 186 keV for 226Ra, 295 and 352 keV for 214Pb, 609, 1120 and 1764 keV for 214Bi, 338, 463, 911 and 968 keV for 228Ac, 727 keV for 212Bi, 238 keV for 212Pb were used for the laboratory measurement of activity concentration. Weighted averages of several decay products were used to estimate the activity concentrations of 226Ra and 232Th.

The net count rate under the most prominent photo peaks of radium and thorium daughter peaks were calculated from respective count rate after subtracting the background counts of the spectrum obtained for the same counting time. Then the activity of the radionuclide was calculated from the background subtracted area of prominent gamma ray energies. Using Eqs. (3)–(5), the absorbed and annual effective dose rates from the samples were calculated. Table 2 presents the minimum and maximum values of absorbed dose. The indoor annual effective dose and outdoor annual effective dose were found to vary from 50 to 95 nGyh−1, 0.24 to 0.46 mSv and 0.06–0.12 mSv, respectively, in the soil samples studied in the present work. Similarly, Table 4 presents the minimum and maximum values of absorbed dose, indoor annual effective dose and outdoor annual effective dose were found to vary from 11 to 57 nGyh−1, 0.05 to 0.28 mSv and 0.01 to 0.07 mSv, respectively, in the building materials studied in the present work. All the samples analyzed in the present work satisfied the criterion, i.e. the annual effective dose of less than 1 mSv, the recommended safety limit for general public [27]. Hence, most of these samples would not pose much health hazard for the population.

Using Eqs. (6)–(7), the internal and external hazard indices from the different samples were calculated. Table 2 presents the range of internal and external hazard indices which varied from 0.1 to 0.2 and 0.4 to 0.7 in various soil samples. Similarly, Table 4 presents the range of internal and external hazard indices which varied from 0.1 to 0.4 and 0.1 to 0.4 in various building materials. Present study shows that, the values of hazard indices in all the samples were less than unity, therefore, according to the Radiation Protection 112 [23] report, soil from these regions and building materials are safe and can be used as a construction material without posing any significant radiological threat to populations.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The results shows that natural radioactivity levels measured in the samples under present study were below the recommended limit. These samples satisfied the universal standards [21] limiting the radioactivity within the safe limits of 1000, 1000 and 4000 Bqkg−1 for 226Ra, 232Th and 40K, respectively. The radium equivalent activities in all the samples were found to be lower than the limit (370 Bq/kg) set in the 1979 Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development report. The results obtained have shown that the indoor and outdoor annual effective doses due to natural radioactivity are lower than the recommended safety limit 1 mSv for general public [27]. However, some of the soil samples (GK and NHS) and building material lime powder (TL) may enhance the radiation dose when used as building construction materials. The calculated values of hazard indices in all the samples were less than unity. Hence, most of the samples under study do not pose much health hazard for the population and can be used as construction materials.
